qas.question: What is the American film industry's trade organization?
The Motion Picture Association of America is which industry's trade organization?
Which country is the world's largest producer of films?
The MPAA has advocated strong protection of what kind of rights?
Congress has advocated a strong protection of what kind of rights?

plausible_answers.text: the property that is produced by their labor

qas.question: What has Congress argued that people are entitled to?
What type of reforms have weakened the MPAA?

plausible_answers.text: the position of the United States as the world's largest producer of films

qas.question: What is Congress aware of that makes it difficult to expand the conception of intellectual property?

context: Also with respect to copyright, the American <a1_0>film<a1_0/> industry helped to change the social construct of intellectual property via its trade organization, the <a0_0>Motion Picture Association of America<a0_0/>. In amicus briefs in important cases, in lobbying before Congress, and in its statements to the public, the MPAA has advocated strong protection of <a3_0><b4_0>intellectual-property<a3_0/> rights<b4_0/>. In framing its presentations, the association has claimed that people are entitled to <b5_0>the property that is produced by their labor<b5_0/>. Additionally Congress's awareness of <b7_0>the position of the <a2_0>United States<a2_0/> as the world's largest producer of films<b7_0/> has made it convenient to expand the conception of intellectual property. These <b6_0>doctrinal<b6_0/> reforms have further strengthened the industry, lending the MPAA even more power and authority.
